metadata.title: Kinetics and mechanism of magnesium sulphite oxidation promoted by a novel cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst

Component SiO2 Al2O3 Na2O MgO Fe2O3 CoO CaO K2O TiO2 Cl (wt%) 46.49 25.42 11.19 2.69 1.50 1.27 0.49 0.44 0.17 0.17 Kinetics and mechanism of magnesium sulphite oxidation promoted by a novel cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst Wang Lidong ⁎ Cui Shuai Li Qiangwei Wang Juan Liu Shuang School of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Baoding 071003, China School of Environmental Science and Engineering North China Electric Power University Baoding 071003 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The oxidation of magnesium sulphite is crucial in recycling the byproduct of magnesium desulphurisation. In this study, a novel cobalt-based catalyst was prepared using a wet impregnation method by loading cobalt species on a molecular sieve carrier. The catalyst was characterised using scanning electron microscopy, X-ray fluorescence, Brunauer–Emmett–Teller analysis, X-ray diffraction, and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. The catalyst was confirmed to be a mesoporous material. The macroscopic kinetics of magnesium sulphite oxidation catalysed by this cobalt-based catalyst was investigated in a stirred tank reactor. The results showed that reaction orders with respect to catalyst, magnesium sulphite, and oxygen concentrations were 0.39, 0, and 0.41, respectively. The apparent activation energy was 35.2kJmol−1. In addition, a comparison of the rates of external diffusion, internal diffusion, and intrinsic reaction revealed that the internal diffusion of oxygen might be the rate-controlling step of magnesium sulphite oxidation. The results provide a new approach for recycling the magnesium desulphurisation byproduct. Keywords Magnesium sulphite Oxidation rate Supported catalyst Recycle Nomenclature c i reactant concentration at the interface between liquid and solid catalyst c A concentration of reactants on the catalyst surface in general c b reactant concentration in the aqueous bulk c Co concentration of cobalt at the phase interfere c O 2 equilibrium concentration of oxygen at the phase interfere c S(VI) concentration of sulphate at the phase interfere D ed external diffusion coefficient D id internal diffusion coefficient k in coefficient of intrinsic reaction rate L pore length which depends on the diameter of catalyst particles mL Thiele modules n reaction orders of oxygen in the intrinsic reaction p reaction orders of sulphite in the intrinsic reaction q reaction orders of cobalt catalyst in the intrinsic reaction r ed external diffusion rate of the reactants which includes oxygen and sulphite r id internal diffusion rate of the reactants which includes oxygen and sulphite r in intrinsic reaction rate of sulphite oxidation 1 Introduction As the main precursor of acid rain and haze, sulfur dioxide (SO2) has become an important environmental issue for several decades. In China, the prominent source of SO2 emissions is from the scattering industrial boilers, which is estimated to be no less than 500,000 units in total amounts before 2014 [1]. Magnesium desulphurisation is a promising technique for flue gas cleaning [2] and has been widely used in industrial boilers [3]. Magnesium hydrate, used as the absorbent, reacts with SO2 and forms insoluble magnesium sulphite, which is then oxidised to form soluble magnesium sulphate [4], a potential fertiliser [5]. However, the oxidation rate of magnesium sulphite, as a pollutant that might release SO2 and consume dissolved oxygen in the water [6], is comparatively low, thus resulting in poor utilisation of the desulphurisation byproduct. The byproduct therefore comprises of both sulphite and sulphate from industrial boilers and must be discarded, which results in wasteful magnesium sulphate consumption and secondary sulphite pollution. Enhancing sulphite oxidation in the presence of a catalyst is reliable and effective and is considered a free radical reaction [7]. Transition metals have been reported to show excellent catalytic performance in accelerating sulphite oxidation [8,9]. Cobalt is the most widely used catalyst for increasing the oxidation rate of sulphite [10–14]. Lancia et al. [15–20] investigated the catalytic effect of manganese ions on sulphite oxidation and calculated the kinetic parameters. Karatza et al. [21] demonstrated the catalytic effect of cuprous ions on sulphite oxidation. Yuegang et al. [22] reported the photochemical oxidation kinetics of sulphite catalysed by ferric ions. Furthermore, Semler et al. [23] studied the catalytic effect of the combination of ferrous and manganese ions on sulphite oxidation. However, these studies focused on the homogeneous catalytic behaviour of transition metal ions in aqueous solutions, which causes critical transition metal ion pollution during the process of sulphite oxidation. Moreover, the consumption (i.e., no recycling) of transition metal ions is financially inviable. Therefore, realizing a recyclable transition metal catalyst is essential for flue gas desulphurisation. Compared with conventional transition metal ion catalysts for sulphite oxidation, solid catalysts deserve more attention because of their ease of recycling, which reduces consumption and secondary pollution. Several methods are available for preparing solid catalysts, such as impregnation, co-precipitation, deposition–precipitation, hydrothermal treatment, urea–nitrate combustion, and sol–gel methods [24]. Using supported catalysts with active ions on the carrier of porous materials, such as molecular sieves [25–28], activated carbons [29,30], and silicone [31,32], is a promising approach that combines the advantages of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Few studies have reported on preparing solid catalysts for increasing sulphite oxidation rates, which confines the recycling of desulphurisation byproducts to coal-fired industrial boilers. For increased byproduct utilisation in magnesium-based desulphurisation, in this study, a novel solid catalyst was prepared to increase the magnesium sulphite oxidation rate. Based on the catalytic performance of transition metal ions, cobalt was selected as the active component and loaded on a molecular sieve carrier through wet impregnation. The oxidation kinetics of magnesium sulphite was investigated in the presence of the supported catalyst, clarifying the oxidation system operation in wet magnesium desulphurisation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and characterisation of the cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst The cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst was prepared through wet impregnation. Molecular sieves (4A) were added to an aqueous solution containing the desired concentration of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and the mixture was rotated in a thermostatic shaker for 4h. After 24h, the mixture was filtered, washed with deionized water, thoroughly oven-dried at 110°C for 8h, calcined at 250°C for 2h, and subsequently calcined at 400°C in a muffle furnace for 3h. The obtained catalyst was ready for use. The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of the catalyst were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM; S4800, Hitachi, Japan). The specific surface area and pore size were evaluated using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller analysis (Tristar 3020, Micromeritics, USA). The components of the catalyst were analysed using wavelength-scanning X-ray fluorescence (XRF; XRF 1700, S4, Bruker, Germany; Table 1 ). The cobalt species on the catalyst surface were identified using X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany). Surface elemental analysis was performed using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, System 7, Thermo Noran, USA). 2.2 Preparation and analysis of magnesium sulphite samples The magnesium sulphite samples were prepared by precipitation of concentrated sodium sulphite and magnesium chloride with vigorous agitation and separation. This precipitate of magnesium sulphite was then washed and placed in a vacuum rotary evaporator (R201L, SENCO, China). The purity of hydrate magnesium sulphite product was 99% which was confirmed by wavelength-scanning X-ray fluorescence (type XRF-1700), EDTA titration, and barium sulphate spectrophotometry [33]. 2.3 Experimental method and apparatus A bubbling apparatus was used to study the catalysed oxidation kinetics of magnesium sulphite [13]. The reaction temperature was kept constant by a water bath (type AMO-C). After supplying 200mL of deionized water, the prepared solid catalyst was added to the reactor. Pure nitrogen, oxygen, and air were blended in a specific ratio through flow adjustment and injected into the reactor as the oxidation gas. The oxygen partial pressure varied from 0.10 to 0.80atm, and the total gas flow rate was kept 60Lh−1. Simultaneously, the reaction was initiated by adding magnesium sulphite (0.085–0.343molL−1) which was dissolved within 30s. A solution of hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide was used to adjust the pH. A trace amount of the reaction solution was pipetted at regular intervals, dissolved in hydrochloric acid, and diluted; the solution volume reduced by approximately 1–2%, which slightly influenced the experimental results. The sulphate concentration at various time points t was determined using barium sulphate spectrophotometry. The results indicated that the sulphate concentration increased linearly with increasing reaction time. Because the overall reaction rate was defined as r = d c d t = d [ SO 4 2 − ] d t , it was calculated based on the slope of the curve which represented the relationship between sulphate concentration and reaction time [13]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterisation of the supported catalyst The SEM images of the molecular sieve before and after cobalt species loading were compared (Fig. 1 ). The surface of fresh molecular sieve was microporous and relatively smooth (Fig. 1(A)). After loading of the cobalt species, a bunch of irregular clusters of spicules grew unevenly on the carrier surface (Fig. 1(B)).These clusters might be a mixture of cobalt monoxide (CoO) and cobalt trioxide (Co2O3). The diameter of a single cluster was approximately 0.1–0.3μm. Fig. 2 shows that the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm of the supported catalyst was a type III isotherm [34], indicating that the catalyst exhibited a low adsorption capacity at low pressures and that the adsorption capacity increased with increasing pressure. Moreover, the prepared catalyst was confirmed to be a mesoporous material with uniform pore size because well-developed H3 type hysteresis loops were observed [34] on the isotherm; the specific surface area was 26.5m2 g−1. Pore size distribution measurement indicated that the dominant bulk of this prepared mesoporous catalyst had an average pore diameter of 17.1nm. Moreover, the distribution peaks were observed at approximately 4nm, consistent with the preparation procedures in which 4A molecular sieves were used as the substrate. The XRF results are reported in Table 1. The cobalt species, CoO, accounted for 1.27wt% of the carrier, proving that the most active components of the cobalt species were effectively loaded on the molecular sieve carrier. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the prepared cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst. Peaks at 36.503° and 42.401° were attributed to CoO, and peaks at 27.769°, 31.137°, 38.609°, and 58.763° were attributed to Co2O3. The intensities of the Co2O3 diffractions peaks were extremely sharp, indicating an increase in particle size and crystallinity and the uneven formation of active catalytic constituents on its surface, which is consistent with the results presented in Fig. 1. The EDS spectra are shown in Fig. 4 . Besides the original elements, such as O, Si, Al, Mg, and Fe (Fig. 4(A)), some amount of cobalt appeared on the molecular sieve because of the loading process. This proved that the active constituent on the molecular sieve surface (Fig. 4(B)) was effective, agreeing well with the result in Table 1. 3.2 Oxidation kinetics of magnesium sulphite in the presence of the supported catalyst The oxidation rates at various catalytic concentrations (Fig. 5 ) were compared with the noncatalysed oxidation rate, indicating that the catalytic oxidation rates markedly increased with increasing catalytic concentration. Furthermore, the catalytic concentration and reaction rate were rendered dimensionless with respect to their initial values. Thus, the reaction order with respect to the supported catalyst concentration was 0.39, as shown in the sub-graph in Fig. 5. The effect of the initial magnesium sulphite concentration on the reaction rate is illustrated in Fig. 6 . The slopes of the regression curves were nearly identical. Thus, the reaction order with respect to the magnesium sulphite concentration was zero. The effect of oxygen partial pressure on the reaction rate is illustrated in Fig. 7 . The reaction rate increased with increasing oxygen partial pressure. According to Henry’s Law, oxygen partial pressure is proportional to the equilibrium oxygen concentration at the gas–liquid interface. The reaction rate and oxygen partial pressure were normalised with respect to their initial values, and the reaction order with respect to the oxygen concentration (Fig. 7) was calculated as 0.41. Fig. 8 shows the effect of pH on the oxidation rate. The oxidation rate increased with increasing pH from 5.0 to 8.0 and decreased with further increase to pH 9.0; the oxidation rate at pH 8.0 was the highest. Thus, the catalytic activity of the catalyst is remarkable at high pH. The effect of temperature on the reaction rate is plotted in Fig. 9 . The reaction rate moderately increased with increasing temperature. Furthermore, a plot of the logarithmic reaction rate versus 1/T is shown in the sub-graph in Fig. 9. The temperature dependency is in accordance with the Arrhenius law in the range 303–333K. According to the slope of the regression curve, the apparent activation energy was 35.2kJmol−1. 3.3 Mechanism of magnesium sulphite oxidation catalysed by the supported catalyst Magnesium sulphite oxidation in the presence of a supported catalyst surface is a complex heterogeneous reaction divided into the following steps: (a) external diffusion, which involves the mass transfer of reactants from the aqueous bulk to the external surface of the catalyst and the diffusion of products from the catalyst surface to the aqueous bulk [35]; (b) internal diffusion, which involves the mass transfer of reactants from the external surface to the internal surface along the pores of the supported catalyst and the diffusion of products from the internal to the external surface; and (c) chemical reaction, which involves the absorption of the reactants and oxidation and desorption of the products. 3.3.1 External diffusion rate r ed The rate of diffusion of reagents from the aqueous bulk to the catalyst surface is expressed as follows (Eq. (1)): (1) r ed = D ed (c b −c i) Considering the catalytic reaction rate, the external diffusion rate is described by Eq. (2) [35]: (2) r ed = c b ( 1 / k i n + 1 / D e d ) Thus, the overall reaction rate, controlled by the external diffusion rate, is represented in the following expression by neglecting the resistance of the chemical reaction: (3) r ed ≈ D ed c b Eq. (3) implies that the overall reaction rate is proportional to the reagent concentration in the bulk as long as it is controlled by external diffusion. Therefore, the overall reaction rate is insensitive to the increase in the reaction temperature, resulting in rather low apparent activation energy (about 4.2–21kJmol−1) [35]. However, this assumption is inconsistent with the observed results in Figs. 6 and 7, which indicate that the overall reaction rate with respect to oxygen and magnesium sulphite concentrations is not 1.0. Furthermore, the dosage of the supported catalyst should slightly influence the reaction rate, which is inconsistent with the results presented in Fig. 5. Moreover, the apparent activity energy was 35.2kJmol−1, which is much higher than that of general reaction controlled by external diffusion [35]. Thus, we infer that the overall oxidation rate is not controlled by external diffusion. 3.3.2 Internal diffusion rate r id Assume that the pore size of the supported catalyst is considerably smaller than that of the reactant or product. The internal diffusion resistance might become dominant in the overall reaction. Thiele modules (mL; dimensionless), were used to reveal the relationship between diffusion resistance and reaction resistance [35] (Eq. (4)): (4) m L = L k in / D int In terms of an irreversible reaction of the n th order, mL is expressed as follows (Eq. (5)): (5) m L = L [ ( n + 1 ) k in c A n − 1 ( 2 D i d ) ] 1 / 2 Thus, the overall reaction rate is expressed as follows (Eq. (6)): (6) r i d = k i n c A n ( 1 / m L ) = k i n c A n ( 1 / L ) [ 2 D i d / ( n + 1 ) k i n c A n − 1 ] 1 / 2 = [ 2 k i n D i d / ( n + 1 ) L 2 ] 1 / 2 c A ( n + 1 ) / 2 Considering all reactants and the catalyst, including oxygen, sulphite, and cobalt species, the internal diffusion rate is expressed as follows (Eq. (7)): (7) r i d = 2 k i n D i d / ( n + 1 ) L 2 1 / 2 c O 2 ( n + 1 ) / 2 c S IV p / 2 c Co q / 2 Thus, the overall reaction rate (controlled by internal diffusion) is related to the intrinsic reaction rate in terms of the reaction order with respect to reagents and their concentrations in the bulk. In addition, the overall reaction rate is more sensitive to the reaction temperature than that controlled by external diffusion. Intrinsic reaction kinetics and internal diffusion are discussed in the subsequent sections. 3.3.3 Intrinsic reaction rate r in The intrinsic reaction rate of sulphite oxidation in the presence of cobalt ions has been deeply investigated, and the reaction rate is expressed as Eq. (8). According to Abdullah's results [36], the reaction order with respect to SO3 2−, oxygen, and cobalt-based catalyst concentrations in an aqueous solution were 1.0, 0, and 1.0, respectively. (8) r in = k in c O 2 n c S ( I V ) p c Co q However, oxidation occurring on the supported catalyst surface in this study differs from the homogeneous reaction described in previous studies. We assumed that the reaction between dissolved SO3 2− and oxygen on the supported catalyst surface proceeds according to the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism [25]. The reactants, including SO3 2− and oxygen, were adsorbed on the active sites, CoOx, on the internal surface of the supported catalyst. Affected by the catalytic CoOx, one of the SO double bonds in SO3 2− might be destroyed for combining with a free oxygen atom to form SO4 2−. The product, SO4 2−, is then desorbed. Thus, the chain reaction in magnesium sulphite oxidation was considerably promoted. Because the amount of active CoOx sites is proportional to its concentration in the bulk, Eq. (8) is still applicable for the analysis of the intrinsic oxidation rate in the presence of the supported catalyst. Therefore, if the overall oxidation rate is controlled by the intrinsic reaction rate, oxygen partial pressure should not affect the overall oxidation rate, which contradicts the results shown in Fig. 7. Another inconsistency with the experimental results was that the reaction order with respect to the supported catalyst concentration was 0.39 (Fig. 5), which should be about 1.0 if the intrinsic reaction was the rate-controlling step. In addition, temperature affects the overall reaction rate because of its dependency on the rate-controlling step (intrinsic reaction). However, the apparent activation energy of the overall oxidation, 35.2kJmol−1 (Fig. 9), is considerably lower than the common reaction controlled by the intrinsic reaction (50kJmol−1), indicating that the overall oxidation rate is mildly sensitive to the reaction temperature. Thus, we infer that intrinsic reaction is not the rate-controlling step. 3.3.4 Overall oxidation rate r The overall oxidation rate depends on the aforementioned slowest steps [32] and is expressed as follows: (9) r =min (r ed, r id, r in) As mentioned in Sections 3.3.1 and 3.3.3, the overall oxidation rate is not controlled by external diffusion or intrinsic reaction. Thus, the only possibility is that overall oxidation is controlled by the internal diffusion of oxygen (Eq. (7)). In our previous research [13], the diffusion of oxygen was confirmed to be the rate-controlling step, and the reaction orders with respect to oxygen and catalyst concentrations were 0.45 and 0.44. Compared with the results in Figs. 5 and 7, a deviation of 10% was observed. This might be caused by the uneven distribution of active cobalt catalyst spreading on the surface of molecular sieve in this work (Fig. 1). The apparent activation energy was observed to be 35.2kJmol−1 which is half of that for the common intrinsic chemical reaction. However, the low apparent activation energy obtained in this work conforms to the feature of heterogeneous reaction controlled by the internal diffusion [35]. Moreover, the magnesium sulphite concentration was slightly influential because it was saturated during oxidation. The pore size observed in this study was smaller (Fig. 2) than the diameter of magnesium sulphite particles, which was estimated to be approximately 169μm in average in our previous study [33]. This probably results in prominent resistance, which prevents the reactants from reaching the internal surface of the supported catalyst and contacting the active cobalt sites. 4 Conclusions A cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst was prepared through wet impregnation to increase the oxidation rate of magnesium sulphite. The supported catalyst was characterised, and the catalytic kinetics of magnesium sulphite oxidation was investigated in a bubbling tank. The reaction orders with respect to cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst, magnesium sulphite, and oxygen concentrations were 0.39, 0, and 0.41, respectively. In addition, the effects of pH and temperature were investigated. The apparent activation energy was 35.2kJmol−1, and internal diffusion of oxygen was concluded to be the rate-controlling step during overall oxidation. The supported catalyst, after being proceeded by shape-forming method, might be applied in the oxidation system according to the operation and layout requirement of wet desulphurization. Due to its porous performance, the supported catalyst could simultaneously remove the heavy metals in the desulphurization slurry as well, which benefits for the multi-pollutants control in the future. coredata.dc:description: The oxidation of magnesium sulphite is crucial in recycling the byproduct of magnesium desulphurisation. In this study, a novel cobalt-based catalyst was prepared using a wet impregnation method by loading cobalt species on a molecular sieve carrier. The catalyst was characterised using scanning electron microscopy, X-ray fluorescence, Brunauer–Emmett–Teller analysis, X-ray diffraction, and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. The catalyst was confirmed to be a mesoporous material. The macroscopic kinetics of magnesium sulphite oxidation catalysed by this cobalt-based catalyst was investigated in a stirred tank reactor. The results showed that reaction orders with respect to catalyst, magnesium sulphite, and oxygen concentrations were 0.39, 0, and 0.41, respectively. The apparent activation energy was 35.2kJmol−1. In addition, a comparison of the rates of external diffusion, internal diffusion, and intrinsic reaction revealed that the internal diffusion of oxygen might be the rate-controlling step of magnesium sulphite oxidation. The results provide a new approach for recycling the magnesium desulphurisation byproduct.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetics and mechanism of magnesium sulphite oxidation promoted by a novel cobalt-based molecular sieve catalyst
